body:
I'm of the opinion that Paul meant to align his teachings with Jesus', but things got lost in the translation. Jesus taught a very simple gospel.  Paul tried to explain it to people who thought very differently than we do now. It's apparent in some of the epistles [1] [2] and even the book of Revelation [3] that many of the early Christians were going astray without constant supervision. In his attempts to clarify the gospel, we might have gotten a muddier message.

2. https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1%20Corinthians%201%3A13-17&version=KJV

3. https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Revelation%202&version=KJV

body:
I think Paul is an important theologian and evangelist.  I don't think that Paul's words necessarily conflict with that of Christ... if taken in full context.  Armchair Christians and atheists obviously have never read the bible, even if they have, they know nothing of the character of Paul and the other apostles or even the history of the area or the customs and traditions of the times.. nor the prevailing attitude of the early Christian church.  Statist "Christians" have contorted the message of peaceful rebellion to one of submitting and pledging yourself to an earthly authoritarian - its how we got the catholic church, orthodox church, divine right rulers...

The most often refutation of Jesus' words from Paul (which I agree with you is quite strange) is Romans 13, and then some others from Peter (1 Peter 2), and Titus.

First, I would consider the character of Paul - a frequent and hostile critic of the Roman Empire who spends much of the time contrasting it unfavorably with the Kingdom being established through Jesus Christ in the church, A man whos demise was by the prevailing pagan authority. Next, you have to ask yourself if Romans 13 gives the authority/government an option to ignore Jesus' commands. If the authority ignores God, are they still legitimate? Of course not. Romans 13 does not legitimize authorities but calls to submit to them as a way of turning the other cheek, to overcome their evil not through violent resistance but with an exemplary attitude that seeks to patiently understand and forgive. This is shown in the previous chapter (Romans 12). Then I would question what earthly government actually follows through on Christ's teachings? None. Especially the imperial cult of the Roman Empire.  With these things in mind, I wonder if the chapter was written in sarcasm, or perhaps written very cautiously in the off chance his letters were intercepted.

This has also been brought up within Christian anarchist theology by Alexandre Christoyannopoulos, Vernard Eller, Jacques Ellul, etc... and I have posted their writings in this guild for further reference.

all-in-all you're right - who cares what the apostles say in comparison to Jesus, but I wouldn't dismiss it entirely.

parent.body:
I'm of the opinion that Paul meant to align his teachings with Jesus', but things got lost in the translation. Jesus taught a very simple gospel.  Paul tried to explain it to people who thought very differently than we do now. It's apparent in some of the epistles [1] [2] and even the book of Revelation [3] that many of the early Christians were going astray without constant supervision. In his attempts to clarify the gospel, we might have gotten a muddier message.
